text: What are the cool kids using for LaTeX these days? I haven't really used it since PhD days, when I was rocking a MikTeX distribution and TeXnicCenter, but presumably the world has moved on? (Tbf I think it had already moved on ~10 years ago when I went with that combination :))

elements.text: What are the cool kids using for LaTeX these days? I haven't really used it since PhD days, when I was rocking a MikTeX distribution and TeXnicCenter, but presumably the world has moved on? (Tbf I think it had already moved on ~10 years ago when I went with that combination :))

text: as IDE, choose from <https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/339/latex-editors-ides> (of course the first one is :emacs:)
I use vscode since I switched to that from atom. Works just fine. Compile with latexmk and lualatex

elements.text: I use vscode since I switched to that from atom. Works just fine. Compile with latexmk and lualatex

text: vscode (with the proper extensions) has been the first latex-editor that doesn't make me miserbale writing latex

elements.text: vscode (with the proper extensions) has been the first latex-editor that doesn't make me miserbale writing latex

text: Just setup reverse search from okular yesterday, can't believe it took me almost half a year to finally spend the two minutes it took to figure out how to get it working :joy:

text: I have had luck making a "standalone" version (MS has a word for this?) specifically for latex so I can enable spell-check (annoying with code) and disable the unicode completion that I like with julia

text: Hmm... I've been trying to switch to VSCode for Julia a few times but always find it lacking compared to Atom, maybe combining it with LaTeX can make it worthwhile?

text: Can I ask what you mean by VSCode LaTeX-instance? Do you have multiple VSCode installations, one for Julia, one for LaTeX?
